Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.10).

Seems dozens of tests got failed due to invoking readFully because that -1 is deemed as an exception. There are some cases when we allocate a bigger buffer but cannot fill up it. Should we throw IOException when channel.read returns -1? If yes, all the enclosing methods should be capture this exception and check if this is as designed or just rethrow it.

Do you all think it's okay if I remove the throwing statement and  restore all the outer checking code (check hasRemaining)? Does this make sense?  @junrao @ijuma @hachikuji

Throws IOException is only reasonable when we really want to fill up the buffer. But in those cases where buffer might not be filled up (at least for those failed cases), invoking readFully should not throw IOException since returnning -1 is definitely as expected.

What readFully must guarantee is that it never leads to a situation where channel still has something to read but buffer does not get filled up.  As a utility method, readFully should not assume channel's EOF is an exceptional case. The enclosing method could take over that responsibility.
